title: Can I sue my bankruptcy attorney for misrepresentation/fraud?
question: I filed chapter 7 on Apr 2011 for $100k debt and was dismissed on Aug 2011 because my lawyer did not provide the document requested by the creditor. Refilled on Dec 2011 and was discharged on Mar 2012. 2 years later, I tried to refinance and found that the creditor I filed the chapter 7 for recorded a lien on Nov 2011 (in between the dismissal date and refilling date). My lawyer did not inform me about the motion to avoid lien until 2 years later when I found out that I have a lien on my house. I filed the motion to avoid lien on Apr 2014 and was denied because I've been paying for my mortgage without fail and the value of my house went up since 2011. Now I have $155k lien on my house. Is there anything I can do? Please help
answers:
There is too much more to this story to really provide any direction here. It doesn't sound like you have any case against your attorney, malpractice or otherwise. Sounds like you just need to follow Mark's advice, get a new attorney, have them review the situation, so you can accomplish what you need to accomplish.

(Generally, motions to avoid liens are excluded from a bankruptcy attorneys services. Since the service must be performed after the case is filed, it is not part of the fee paid prior to filing. As such, you must pay more for your attorney to file the motion).

I haven't researched this in a while, but I'm fairly certain that here in the 9th Circuit, the relevant date for valuation on your Motion to Avoid Lien is the date your bankruptcy case was filed (December 2011), not the date you filed your motion.

If you used the value of your property on the date you filed the motion, that was likely incorrect. When I do these, I always have my clients get a retroactive appraisal done by a real estate broker, and I have never had an issue.

I'd need to see the Motion and all related documents to be sure, but you may want to consider re-filing the Motion to Avoid Lien (which at this point would also require a motion to reopen your case).

A bankruptcy case would not be dismissed because your attorney did not provide the document requested by a creditor. It might have been dismissed because a document was not provided that had been requested by the Trustee assigned to your case. While it is possible you provided the requested document to your attorney and he failed to provide it in a timely manner, why would he do so?

For your second filing, generally in order to get a lien on property, a plaintiff has to file a lawsuit against the debtor and the debtor (you) has to be notified that someone has filed a lawsuit against you and you should have been served with a copy of that lawsuit and you should have had an opportunity to respond to that lawsuit. I suppose you might have an action against your former attorney for malpractice for failing to find that lien and for failing to have filed the motion to avoid the judicial lien in a timely fashion. But fraud? No.

Typically the value of the home in a lien avoidance action is the date the second petition was filed. I would have to read the Court's opinion in denying the motion. In situations like these, an expert in the field of real estate is critical.
I agree with Mr. Markus and suggest you see a legal malpractice atty in your area to see if you have a good case
